description:
Anopheles epiroticus is a species of mosquito belonging to the genus Anopheles, which includes many important malaria vector species. It is primarily found in parts of Greece and Albania, as well as in some neighboring regions.

Anopheles epiroticus is a relatively small mosquito, with a body length typically ranging from 4 to 6 millimeters. The species is characterized by its dark-colored body and wings, with distinctive pale-colored markings on the wings. The legs also exhibit banded patterns.

As an Anopheles mosquito, Anopheles epiroticus is capable of transmitting the Plasmodium parasites that cause malaria in humans. However, its specific role as a malaria vector may vary depending on the geographic location and local epidemiological conditions.

The breeding habitats of Anopheles epiroticus are typically associated with freshwater, including pools, streams, and rice fields. The females of the species require a blood meal, often from humans, to produce and lay their eggs.

Further research on the biology, ecology, and vectorial capacity of Anopheles epiroticus may contribute to a better understanding of its potential role in malaria transmission and the development of targeted control strategies in the regions where it is found.
